AviSynth v3 Build Documentation

Version:
0.2.2
Author:
Wilbert Dijkhof <wilbertdijkhof at yahoo.com>

Vincent Torri <torri at math dot iecn dot u-nancy dot fr>

Date:
2004
The windows version of AviSynth v3 can be built using MinGW (g++) or VC++ .NET 2003 (VC 7.1). The linux version requires MinGW (g++). Section 1. Building AviSynth v3 for Windows using MinGW (g++) describes how to compile it using MinGW, section 2. Building AviSynth v3 for Windows using VC++ .NET 2003 (VC 7.1) how to compile it using VC++ .NET 2003. Section 4. Building AviSynth v3 for GNU/Linux x86 (using g++) describes how to built the linux version of AviSynth v3.

1. Building AviSynth v3 for Windows using MinGW (g++)

1.1 Installing MinGW (g++)

You need to install the following programs in order to use MinGW:

  • MSYS-1.0.10.exe

    Install it somewhere (for example in C:/Msys/1.0/***). Warning: don't install it in 'C:/Program Files/Msys/***' or any other folder with an empty space in it, because the compiler doesn't like that.

  • mingw-3.1.0.exe

    Install it in C:/Msys/1.0/mingw

  • msysDTK-1.0.1.exe

    Install it in C:/Msys/1.0

  • mingw-runtime-3.5.tar.gz

    Unzip it in C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/

  • w32api-3.1.tar.gz

    Unzip it in C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/

  • setting PATH variables

    Add to the 'path variables' the folders C:/Msys/1.0/bin and C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/bin

    For W2K for example : go to the desktop, right click on 'My Computer' -> Properties -> Advanced tab -> Environment Variables -> select the Variable 'path' -> edit -> add the two folders above:

    ***;C:/Msys/1.0/bin;C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/bin

  • Finally, check whether Msys and MinGW are installed correctly:

    W2K: go to the desktop, double click on 'MSYS'. The MINGW32 terminal (or shell) will pop up, and you will see something like this

    Wilbert@WD ~
$

    Try the following (the commands are linux commands):

    Wilbert@WD ~
$ cd /usr/mingw/bin
$ ./g++

    if you installed everything correctly, you should get

    $ ./g++
g++.exe: no input files

    To compile AviSynth v3 using the configuration file which is located in ../avisynth/build/linux (it is modified so that avs 3.0 can be compiled with g++ under windows), but we need to compile STLport, Boost and Freetype first, which is described in the following sections.

1.2 Description MinGW (g++)

In the previous subsection, a brief overview was given explaining which components have to be installed. This subsection will give a short description of the components. The reader who is not interested in this, can proceed with 1.4 Installing STLport.

1.2.1 MSYS

A Minimal SYStem to provide configure scripts the ability to execute and create a Makefile used by make.

1.2.2 MinGW

MinGW or 'Minimalist GNU for Windows'. It's a collection of freely available and freely distributable Windows specific header files and import libraries combined with GNU toolsets that allow one to produce native Windows programs that do not rely on any 3rd-party C runtime DLLs.

1.2.3 msysDTK

An extra package of MSys (Developer ToolKit).

1.2.4 mingw-runtime

Free Microsoft C Runtime and import library definitions.

1.2.5 w32api

Free headers and libraries for the Win32 API.

1.3 Obtaining the AviSynth v3 source

Get the sources from their website.

Open a MINGW32 terminal (CVS is already included in MinGW) and use the following command

$ cvs -d:pserver:anonymous@cvs.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/avisynth2 co -r avisynth_3_0 avisynth

This will get you the AviSynth v3 branch in a folder called "avisynth" (note "co" means "check out", and "-r" will get you the branch).

1.4 Installing STLport

STLport is a multiplatform ANSI C++ Standard Library implementation. In order to install it you should

  • Get STLPort-4.6.2.tar.gz and unzip it somewhere.

  • Copy the ../STLport-4.6.2/stlport folder to C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/include/stlport and copy the ../STLport-4.6.2/stlport/stl folder to C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/include/stlport.

  • Edit the file common-macros.mak which is located here: ../STLport-4.6.2/src, and change line 46: replace INSTALLDIR=/usr/local by INSTALLDIR=/usr/mingw

  • Compile the make file gcc-mingw32.mak (in ../STLport-4.6.2/src):

    Go to the terminal again, and type

    $ cd /f/.../STLport-4.6.2/src

    or wherever you installed it. Now, type

    $ make -f gcc-mingw32.mak

    and

    $ make -f gcc-mingw32.mak install

    Now, it should have created the following libraries in ../STLport-4.6.2/lib :

    • libstlport_mingw32_static.a (the static-release library, this one will be used when compiling avs3)
    • libstlport_mingw32*.a (debug libraries)

  • Copy libstlport_mingw32_static.a (located in ../STLport-4.6.2/lib) to C:/Msys/1.0/usr/mingw/lib (if it isn't already there).

1.5 Installing Boost

Boost is a bunch of useful libraries (here it is used for the parser, threads and pointers). BJam (or BoostJam) is a make replacement that makes building simple things simple and building complicated things manageable.

  • Get boost_1_31_0.tar.gz and unzip it somewhere.

  • Get boost-jam-3.1.10-1-ntx86.zip and unzip it to C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/bin.

  • Open a terminal again, go to ../boost_1_31_0 and type

    $ bjam "-sTOOLS=mingw" --prefix=/usr/mingw install

    The libraries are created in: ../boost_1_31_0/bin/boost/libs.

  • Make sure that you copy boost_thread-mgw-mt-1_31.dll to the windows system folder.

1.6 Installing Freetype

Freetype is a free, high-quality, and portable font engine.

Get freetype-2.1.9.tar.gz and unzip it somewhere. Go to the freetype folder and type

$ ./configure --prefix=/usr/mingw
$ make
$ make install

to compile and install it.

1.7 Installing needed circular_buffer source files

Get circular_buffer_v3.6.zip (you can also find it in the avisynth/build folder when downloading the sources of AviSynth) and unzip it in the following way:

  • circular_buffer.hpp and circular_buffer_fwd.hpp should be copied to

    C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/include/boost-1_31/boost

  • adaptor.hpp, base.hpp, debug.hpp and details.hpp should be copied to

    C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/include/boost-1_31/boost/circular_buffer

1.8 Installing Nasm

Nasm or 'the Netwide ASseMbler' is used for optimization of some of the AviSynth code.

Get nasm-0.98.36-win32.zip and unzip it somewhere. Put nasmw.exe in C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/bin, and rename it to nasm.exe (see also here).

1.10 Building AviSynth v3

Open a MINGW32 terminal and go to

../avisynth/build/linux

You need to creat the configure file first which is used to build AviSynth. Type

$ ./bootstrap.sh

The configure file is created, and finally AviSynth can be build:

$ ./configure --with-stl-path=/usr/mingw/ --with-boost-path=/usr/mingw
$ make
$ make install

to compile and install it.

2. Building AviSynth v3 for Windows using VC++ .NET 2003 (VC 7.1)

To successfully compile AviSynth v3 with Microsoft Visual C++ .NET 2003, you first need to obtain some additional libraries and tools. The order in which you compile them is important, so please follow this small guide.

I used a folder C:/dev/ to put everything in. If you want to put the stuff somewhere else, don't forget to change the paths accordingly.

2.1 Obtaining the AviSynth v3 source

Get the sources from their website.

It is assumed you have installed WinCVS or TortoiseCVS, otherwise you have to do that first. You can use either the gui to get the avisynth_3_0 branch, or the command prompt (for W2K for example: go to the desktop, right click on 'My Computer' -> Properties -> Advanced tab -> Environment Variables -> select the Variable 'path' -> edit -> add the path to WinCVS/TortoiseCVS where cvs.exe is located) to get it:

Make an empty folder called: C:/dev (or whatever). Open a command prompt and use the following commands

cd C:/dev
C:/dev> cvs -d:pserver:anonymous@cvs.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/avisynth2 co -r avisynth_3_0 avisynth

This will get you the AviSynth v3 branch (note "co" means "check out", and "-r" will get you the branch).

2.2 Obtaining and installing NASM assembler

Get nasm version 0.98.36. This is not the latest version, but 0.98.38 has been known to cause problems. Unzip it. Rename nasmw.exe to nasm.exe. Next, set the path to nasm.exe in VC:

Start up VC.net and

  • In the top menu, go to Tools, Options.
  • In the Options box, select the Projects, VC++ Directories in the tree on the left.
  • In the "Show directories for:" pull-down menu, choose "Executable files".
  • Click the "new Line" button (with the yellow folder on it).
  • Browse to the folder where you unpacked nasm.
  • Click the open button. The path is now added to the list.

Close the dialog boxes and close VC.net.

2.3 Obtaining and compiling the STLport library

Get STLport-4.6.2, and unpack the archive to C:/dev (you can unpack tar.gz files with winzip).

Open up a command prompt and give the following commands (assuming everything ended up in a folder C:/dev/STLPORT-4.6.2/):

C:/dev/STLport-4.6.2> "c:/Program files/Microsoft Visual Studio .NET 2003/Common7/Tools/vsvars32.bat"
C:/dev/STLport-4.6.2> cd src
C:/dev/STLport-4.6.2> nmake -f vc71.mak clean all
C:/dev/STLport-4.6.2> cd ../lib
C:/dev/STLport-4.6.2> copy STLPORT_VC7146.dll %WinDir%/System32/

If you installed Visual Studio in a different location, don't forget to adjust the path to vsvars32.bat. Don't forget the double quotes!

  • In the top menu, go to Tools, Options.
  • In the Options box, select the Projects, VC++ Directories in the tree on the left.
  • In the "Show directories for:" pull-down menu, choose "Include files".
  • Click the "new Line" button (with the yellow folder on it).
  • Browse to C:/dev/STLport-4.6.2/stlport/.
  • Click the "open" button.
  • If the new line is not at the top of the list, use the arrow buttons on the right of the box to put the STL path there.
  • In the "Show directories for:" pull-down menu, choose "Library files".
  • Click the "new Line" button (with the yellow folder on it).
  • Browse to C:/dev/STLport-4.6.2/lib/.
  • Click the "open" button.

Close the dialog boxes and close VC.net.

2.4 Obtaining and compiling the Boost library

Get boost_1_31_0.zip and unzip the archive to c:/dev.

You now should have a folder C:/dev/boost_1_31_0/

You also need an add-on to boost: circular_buffer. This is included with the AviSynth source and can be found here: C:/dev/avs_v3/avisynth/build/circular_buffer_v3.6.zip

  • Unpack the C:/dev/avs_v3/avisynth/build/circular_buffer_v3.6.zip to C:/dev/.
  • Copy the contents of C:/dev/circular_buffer/boost/ to C:/dev/boost_1_31_0/boost/.
  • Copy the contents of C:/dev/circular_buffer/libs/ to C:/dev/boost_1_31_0/libs/.

To compile boost, you need bjam, a "make" replacement. Get it here:

In it you will find bjam.exe. Copy bjam.exe to C:/dev/boost_1_31_0/

Next, compile Boost. Open up a command prompt and give the following commands (assuming everything ended up in a folder C:/dev/boost_1_31_0/):

C:/dev/BOOST_1_31_0>"c:/Program files/Microsoft Visual Studio .NET 2003/Common7/Tools/vsvars32.bat" 
C:/dev/BOOST_1_31_0>bjam "-sTOOLS=vc7.1-stlport" "-sSTLPORT_PATH=C:/dev" stage

You will see some errors about boost.python and file not found error's. These can safely be ignored. The only important thing is that when bjam is finished, C:/dev/boost_1_31_0/stage/lib/boost_thread-vc71-mt-p-1_31.lib was created. Make sure that you copy this dll to your Windows system folder.

Next, add a new include path and library path, just as in 2.3 Obtaining and compiling the STLport library:

  • Add C:/dev/boost_1_31_0/stage/lib/ to the Library paths.
  • Add C:/dev/boost_1_31_0/boost/ to the Include path.

2.5 Obtaining and compiling Freetype

(This step may become obsolete shortly.)

Get freetype 2.1.9 (ft219.zip) and unpack the zip to C:/dev.

Edit C:/dev/freetype-2.1.9/include/freetype/config/ftconfig.h, look up line 276 and change

#define FT_EXPORT( x )  extern "C" x
into 
#define FT_EXPORT( x )  extern "C" x __cdecl

(If you use notepad, which does not have a line count, do a search on "#define FT_EXPORT( x ) extern "C"". It only appears once in this file.)

  • In VC.net, go to file, open solution.
  • Open C:/dev/freetype-2.1.9/builds/win32/visualc/freetype.sln.
  • In the menu, set the solution configuration pull-down to "Release".
  • In the menu, select "Build", "Build Solution".

You will get a bunch of warnings, but it should compile ok.

Next, add a new include path and library path, just as in 2.3 Obtaining and compiling the STLport library:

  • Add C:/dev/freetype-2.1.9/objs/ to the Library paths.
  • Add C:/dev/freetype-2.1.9/include/ to the Include path.

2.6 Compiling AviSynth v3

  • In VC.net, go to file, open solution.
  • Open C:/dev/avs_v3/avisynth/build/win32/vc71/avisynth.sln.
  • In the menu, set the solution configuration pull-down to "Release".
  • In the menu, select "Buid", "Build Solution".

You now should have an avisynth.dll in C:/dev/avs_v3/avisynth/build/win32/vc71/Release/

2.7 Additional remarks I - UPX

The avisynth.dll will be quite big. It can be compressed using UPX:

upx -9 -k avisynth.dll

You may need to use the -f switch to force it to pack.

2.8 Additional remarks II: Standard edition

The receipt above also works with the standard edition of VC++ .NET 2003, which is also included with the learning edition. However, this version of VC contains the non-optimizing compiler. As a result, AviSynth will be a bit slower.

There is a way around this: the Microsoft Visual C++ Toolkit 2003, a free download, contains the optimizing version. Install it, and go to:

C:/Program files/Microsoft Visual C++ Toolkit 2003/bin/

Copy the files c2.dll and cl.exe (do make backups of the originals first!!!) to:

C:/Program Files/Microsoft Visual Studio .NET 2003/Vc7/bin/

The optimization options in the gui will still be greyed out. However, optimization switches already in a project file will be passed on to the compiler. And programs compiled on the command prompt will use it directly.

3. Building FFsource for Windows

3.1 Getting the ffmpeg sources

ffmpegsource can only be build using MinGW, which will be described here.

Get the sources from their website: Open a MinGW terminal, and type:

$ cvs -d:pserver:anonymous@mplayerhq.hu:/cvsroot/ffmpeg co ffmpeg

The ffmpeg folder with its sources will be copied to it (note "co" means "check out").

3.2 Compiling ffmpeg

Go to the ffmpeg folder and type

$ ./configure --enable-memalign-hack --enable-gpl --prefix=/usr/mingw --enable-shared

It will produce 2 dlls that are needed, avcodec.dll and avformat.dll.

Now, to compile it type

$ make

and

$ make install

The dlls and ffmpeg.exe will be installed in C:/Program Files/ffmpeg (for some reason the --prefix directive is ignored). Both dlls should be put in the Windows system folder or, if you set up correctly your PATH previously, in C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/bin.

When you did ./configure, you got the following libs:

../ffmpeg/libavcodec/avcodec.lib
../ffmpeg/libavformat/avformat.lib

copy them to C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/lib.

Copy the 'C:/Program Files/ffmpeg/include/ffmpeg' folder to the include folder of mingw 'C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/include'. (so, 'C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/include/ffmpeg' will be created)

3.3 FFsource temporary

The following is temporary till FFsource is turned into a plugin:

You need to include the following files to the avs project:

in ../avisynth/src/filters/source ffmpegsource.cpp ffmpegsource.h

in ../avisynth/src/functions source.cpp source.h

If you haven't done so, you should do the following first:

$ ./bootstrap.sh
$ ./configure --with-stl-path=/usr/mingw/include/stlport --with-boost-path=/usr/mingw/include/boost-1_31

Edit platform.inc (in ../avisynth/build/linux) and go down to Compiler part. Change the lines

CXX=g++\n
SPECIFIC_CFLAGS=-Os -mno-cygwin\n
FREETYPE_CFLAGS=-I/usr/mingw/include/freetype2 -I/usr/mingw/include\n
CXXFLAGS=-Wall -fstrength-reduce -finline-functions -freduce-all-givs -ffast-math -ansi  -I/usr/mingw/include/stlport  -I/usr/mingw/include/boost-1_31

into

CXX=g++\n
SPECIFIC_CFLAGS=-Os -mno-cygwin\n
FREETYPE_CFLAGS=-I/usr/mingw/include/freetype2 -I/usr/mingw/include\n
CXXFLAGS=-Wall -fstrength-reduce -finline-functions -freduce-all-givs -ffast-math  -I/usr/mingw/include/stlport  -I/usr/mingw/include/boost-1_31  -I/usr/mingw/include/ffmpeg

(you are basically removing -ansi option) Edit sources.inc (in ../avisynth/build/linux), and add the following line

filters/source/ffmpegsource.cpp

to the list from SRC_GENERIC.

In C:/Msys/1.0/mingw/include/, edit initguid.h: replace const by static const.

Finally, build AviSynth

$ make
$ make install

4. Building AviSynth v3 for GNU/Linux x86 (using g++)

To install Avisynth 3.0, we will need the following libraries:
  • STLPort
  • Boost
  • Freetype
  • FFMpeg or Gstreamer
This section explains how to install these libraries, taking into account the system. We will download all the libraries in the same directory, say avs_main_dir, in the home directory. In a terminal, type 
cd
mkdir avs_main_dir

Note:
Shell commands are given throughout this section. Commands in each subsection are independant and can (have to ?) be used as is to install the libraries.

4.1 Installing STLPort

The current stable version of STLPort is 4.6.2. This version can not be built on systems using glibc 2.3 or above. To know which version of glibc installed on the computer, just type in a terminal 
ls /lib/libc-*
One can see the number of the version of your glibc. If the version is 2.3 or above, one must install the CVS version of STLPort, otherwise, it is sufficient to install the 4.6.2 version of STLPort.

4.1.1 Installing STLPort 4.6.2

First, download STLPort 4.6.2 in the avs_main_dir directory. Go into this directory, uncompress the file and go to the src directory of STLPort: 
cd avs_main_dir
tar zxvf STLport-4.6.2.tar.gz
cd STLport-4.6.2/src
By default, STLPort will be installed in /usr/local. If one wants to change that, edit the common_macros.mak file and change the INSTALLDIR variable as desired. Then to compile and install STLPort 4.6.2, just type the following commands: 
make -f gcc.mak prepare
make -f gcc.mak install

4.1.2 Installing STLPort 5.0 CVS

Because of some evil includes, if glibc 2.3 or above is installed, one has to install the cvs version of STLPort (which will be the future 5.0 version). The installation is not as simple as in the stable version. First we have to download the cvs code of STLPort: 
cd
cd avs_main_dir
cvs -d :pserver:cvs@cvs.stlport.com:/stlport login
A password will be required. Just strike the Enter key. Then, download the code with that command: 
cvs -d :pserver:cvs@cvs.stlport.com:/stlport co -rSTLPORT_5_0 STLport
Then, go to the directory where gcc.mak is located. When this document has been written, it was in the src/explore directory: 
cd STLport/src/explore
To compile the code, execute the following commands: 
make -f gcc.mak depend
make -f gcc.mak install
The libraries are located in STLport/lib and the headers in STLport/stlport.
  • If one wants to install STLPort in /usr, go the the STLport directory and copy the files manually (while being root, of course): 
    cd ../..
su <type the root password>
cp lib/libstlport* /usr/lib/
cp -R stlport /usr/include/
<Ctrl-d>
  • If one wants to install it locally, say for example $HOME/local, just do that: 
    cd ../..
cp lib/libstlport* $HOME/local/lib/
cp -R stlport $HOME/local/include/

4.2 Installing Boost 1.32

First, download Boost 1.32 from SourceForge, put it in avs_main_dir and untar it: 
cd
cd avs_main_dir
tar zxvf boost_1_32_0.tar.gz
Boost does not use the GNU make utility to compile. Instead it uses Boost.Jam (an extension or Perforce Jam. Download the prebuilt executable here. Download it in avs_main_dir and untar it: 
tar zxvf boost-jam-3.1.10-1-linuxx86.tgz
Now, go to the Boost 1.32 diretory and compile it with the following commands: 
cd boost_1_32_0
../boost-jam-3.1.10-1-linuxx86/bjam "-sTOOLS=gcc" --prefix=/usr/ install
In this example, the installation directory of Boost will be /usr/. So you need to be root to install it. If one wants to install it locally (like in 4.1 Installing STLPort), just replace --prefix=/usr/ by --prefix=$HOME/local/.

Note:
For more informations about installing Boost, go to the Installation section of Boost.

4.3 Installing Freetype 2.1.9

Avisynth 3.0 displays text with a very efficient font engine, named Freetype.
Note:
The current version stable 2.1.9 has a small problem in the vertical alignment of the characters. It has been solved in the CVS version. But for the sake of simplicity (and as it is difficult to see this problem), we will install only the stable version of Freetype. For those who want to install the CVS version, go to CVS Freetype section.
First download Freetype 2.1.9 in the avs_main_dir directory, untar it and compile it: 
cd
cd avs_main_dir
tar zxvf freetype-2.1.9.tar.gz
cd freetype-2.1.9
./configure --prefix/usr/
make
make install
This installs Freetype in /usr/, so you have to be root before doing make install. If one wants to install it elsewhere, change the value given to the --prefix parameter.

4.4 Installing FFMPEG

FFMPEG is a set of library the allows to record, convert and stream audio and video. For now, only version 0.4.9-pre1 is working with Avisynth 3.0. Dowload it at SourceForge in avs_main_dir. Untar it, go into its directory, configure it and install it: 
cd
cd avs_main_dir/
tar zxvf ffmpeg-0.4.9-pre1.tar.gz
cd ffmpeg-0.4.9-pre1
./configure --prefix=/usr/
make
make install
make installlib
This installs FFMPEG in /usr/, so you have to be root before doing make installlib. If you want to install it elsewhere, change the value given to the --prefix parameter.

4.5 Assembly support with NASM

If you want to compile Avisynth 3.0 with assembly support, you have to install at least Nasm 0.98.36. This installation is not described yet.

4.6 Building Avisynth 3.0

Now, we may build Avisynth 3.0 ! Just after having installed 3 more libraries.

Ok, ok, I'm kidding...

First we have to download the source code which is in cvs: 

cd
cd avs_main_dir
cvs -d:pserver:anonymous@cvs.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/avisynth2 login
cvs -z3 -d:pserver:anonymous@cvs.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/avisynth2 co -r avisynth_3_0 avisynth

Avisynth 3.0 needs an extension to boost, not yet included in the current version of boost. This extension is provided in the build directory of avisynth. It suffices to unzip it and copy the files to the boost include directory: 

cd avisynth/build
unzip circular_buffer_v3.6.zip
cd circular_buffer
  • If Boost is installed in /usr, you have to be root: 
    su <enter the root password>
cp -R boost /usr/include/boost-1_32/
<Ctrl-d>
  • If Boost is installed in, say $HOME/local: 
    cp -R boost $HOME/local/include/boost-1_32/
And now, we can configure Avixynth 3.0. 
cd ../linux
./booststrap.sh
./configure
If configure is not able to find automatically one or more library, we have to specify its path. Assuming that you have installed everything in /usr/: 
./configure --with-stl-path=/usr --with-boost-path=/usr --with-ffmpeg-path=/usr --with-freetype-config=/usr/bin/freetype-config
If you have installed some of the above libraries elsewhere, just replace /usr by the correct path. The configure script should be able to find automatically FFMPEG and Freetype.

Note:
If you want to make a debug build of Avisynth 3.0, just pass to the configure script the options ----enable-core-debug (for Avisynth itself) and --enable-ffmpeg-debug (for FFMPEG).
To build Avisynth, we use the usual commands: 
make
make install

5. Errors when using AviSynth

If you get the following error AVI Import filter error: (unknown) (80040154) in a messagebox. This error is due to missing dlls, usually ffmpeg's ones (avcodec.dll and avformat.dll). So, copy them to your windows system folder.

Todo:

  • Talk about ACM with mingw.
  • Installation of nasm on linux.
Generated on Sun Dec 12 15:50:36 2004 for Avisynth by 1.3.8
